history.content:
apply early and apply often!

one of my friends applied to 500 companies as a sophomore before getting her internship at Amazon.

every coding challenge, every phone interview, every onsite, prepares you somewhat. if you have the time, then go for it!

children.subject:
Thanks for this. I definitely understand that the rest of my life isn't exactly riding on the hope that I'll get an internship this summer, but I think it's definitely good to get experience as early on as possible.

My question was more geared to the fact that I don't exactly have a lot of skills at the moment, so I'm still trying to decide whether or not to invest too much time applying right now if Spring semester has lots of opportunities anyways and I'll be more prepared to interview then.

Based on your response,

I think you should apply everywhere after you get resume checked(which you should do tomorrow from peers, and monday at career center), and do cracking the coding interview tomorrow morning and everyday if you can. You might not get anything even after applying to 10000 places, you might get 10000 offers after applying. What you can control is your application, interview prep, the career fairs/info sessions you attend, and the fact that you're doing great and if it doesn't happen, it doesn't happen.

If it doesn't happen, (highly doubtful you won't get an internship if you keep trying until June 2019), you'll probably have an even better summer hanging out with your family or traveling the world. I have somewhat of an unpopular opinion that traveling and being with family is more important than internships, but internships are great so it's awesome you're applying now!

Spring has lots of opportunities but a lot of companies you may be focusing on will be done recruiting by January. So do start applying by Monday

Oh, if you don't have skills, think again. CS 61b is all you need to be a beast at an internship! You may be thinking, "that's not true" and you're right. I think the best qualities of an intern is how nice they are, and how persistent they are when solving problems, and how humble they are to ask questions, and how confident they are to ask the 10th question within an hour.

Just read Ashwinee's response. This is absolutely correct, these coding challenges and interview prep will help you succeed future interviews, especially if you self reflect after each one. You're doing awesome wanting to apply and interview now, keep it up!

Tons of opportunities in the Spring too. You're doing great, start studying Cracking Coding Interview tomorrow! Apply now, get that resume checked by people and things will come into place. I think it's chill to apply to companies now and then apply again next year.

You don't need internships to get your dream job, and you don't need a dream job to be happy. Internships are a good time, so getting them is cool too!

history.content:
Sophomore here. I feel like at this present moment, I don't have enough qualifications to apply for the internships I want to apply to. I don't have any good side projects and I'm already rusty on 61B data structures/algo questions (I've taken 61A/B, now doing 61C/70). 

I definitely want to try to get internships this summer, but I also know that some companies have a policy of you not being able to re-apply if you get rejected until months or even a year. So, as a question to older students who maybe had a similar experience to me, would it be just best to put off actual applying for internships until Spring, or should I actively apply right now anyways? I know a lot of intern opportunities close by the end of this semester, but I also want to give myself the chance to actually build up projects/practice interview & coding questions.
history.subject: Best time for intern apps?
